reading_mnemonic: You've already learned 漬ける (to pickle something), so just take the る off and you've pickled whatever comes before 〜漬け. Easy peasy.
The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. 舞い comes from 舞う.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The 一 becomes いっ.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The いち is shortened to いっ.
The reading comes from 一般 plus 的.
The reading comes from 乗る and 換える.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
You need <vocabulary>to accompany</vocabulary> your friend, so to call out to them you yell "<reading>友, NOW</reading>!" (ともなう) to command them to come near you to accompany you to somewhere else.
The reading comes from 伸びる, so if you know that you should know this.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 合 is read as ごう here. Who orchestrated this <vocabulary>annexation</vocabulary>? Good ol' grandpa ごういち.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
You <reading>cut a moo</reading> (かたむ), that is, a cow, in half. Then you request it is leaned up against the fence so you can start harvesting its meat for sustenance.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading follows on'yomi protocols, but you just have to be careful of the shortened しゅつ which becomes しゅっ.

Note: There is also the reading <reading>でどころ</reading> for the meanings <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>source</vocabulary>. This version is generally used in spoken language, often to emphasize the significance or curiosity about where something came from.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading is like 変える, which is to change. So, if you change what the other person is saying to another way, then you're saying you're changing things. It has the same reading, so remember it that way.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 及ぶ, so if you know that one you know that one <vocabulary>as well as</vocabulary> this one.
The reading comes from 及ぶ, so if you know that, you'll be able to read this one too.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This word uses the kun'yomi reading for the first kanji and the on'yomi reading for the second. You've learned both of the readings, so you should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned おく when you learned the kanji, and ふかい from 深い, so you should be able to read this on your own. Most of the time the ふ is rendaku'd into ぶ, but it can be read the other way too.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that rendaku turns へき into ぺき.
The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 廃止 as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
You decide <vocabulary>to risk</vocabulary> it all and bet everything on your <reading>ca</reading>r (か). If you lose, you lose the car, but if you win, then you were right to stake it all on this.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: "How many things are in this <vocabulary>cluster</vocabulary>?" asks your boss. "Just a <reading>few sah</reading>," (ふさ) you reply.
The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, actually! Can you handle that?
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading comes from 指摘.

The reading is the same as 書く, which is similar to drawing something (you use a writing instrument on a piece of paper, which you can do with drawing). Another reading is えがく, which is like saying 絵を書く, but combined and rendaku'd.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The にち goes to にっ.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You may have seen this reading for 朝 before, but here's a mnemonic to help you:

You pick up your copy of the <vocabulary>morning edition</vocabulary> and Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう) is on the front cover. Oh no, what has she done now? Before you can find out, the morning edition is ripped from your hands. You look up and see Mrs. Chou running away, cackling, with other copies stuffed into her arms.

The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You've never seen more <vocabulary>yawning</vocabulary> than when you performed <reading>acu</reading>puncture (あく) on a <reading>bee</reading> (び). It was so relaxed from being the one poked for once that it just couldn't stop yawning.
The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, put together.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of 豆腐 and the kun'yomi reading of 湯. You should be able to read this on your own. Will of course help to know 豆腐 as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to use the kun'yomi reading. The tricky part is where this doesn't use the same kun'yomi as 炒める, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember this:

Now that you know the difference between frying and roasting, we're going <vocabulary>to roast</vocabulary> our first dish: <reading>Ea</reading>gle (い)! I heard it's your favorite food, so I just had to prepare this for you. What do you mean, "eww"?!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You didn't learn this reading for 由 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you had good <vocabulary>lineage</vocabulary> you'd never make a <reading>U-ey</reading> (ゆい) on the highway. That's dangerous, and people with good lineage and a long history would simply never do such a thing.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the reading from the vocabulary you learned earlier. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so feel nice and loose and move on to the next item.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!
The reading comes from what you learned with the kanji.
The reading is 縄 and 張る put together into one word.
The reading you learned with the kanji is used here.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own.
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're walking around in your mom's house, minding your own business, when you slam your <vocabulary>kneecap</vocabulary> right into that <reading>ga</reading>rgoyle <reading>she love</reading>s (がしら). It hurts so bad, you can't even think out that phrase and instead you shout out, "GA SHE RA" and fall to the floor, clutching your searing kneecap (which has probably broken in half).

What are you going <vocabulary>to do</vocabulary>? You're going to become a professional <reading>eater</reading> (いた), because you like to do eating a lot, and you are very polite about your eating despite how fast you eat in these competitions.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading for this one is unusual, but I will entrust you with the knowledge of why to help you remember it! This uses the on'yomi reading and not the kun'yomi, as you might expect, because the す here is the old-fashioned version of the verb する.

Luckily, you learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so it's unusual but hopefully not too hard!
The reading for the 易 portion is a bit weird. Just think about how this one trade firm only trades in train <reading>station</reading>s (えき).
You need to make a payment, <reading>make a</reading> payment <reading>now</reading> (まかなう) <vocabulary>to cover</vocabulary> the cost of this room.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
If you want to give someone a present, maybe you would think about <reading>send</reading>ing/送る (おくる) it to them?
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Who likes <vocabulary>to exceed</vocabulary> everything? Your <reading>子</reading> (こ)! Or you, when you were a 子. No bedtimes, parents, or other limitations could stop you! You were able to go over them all!
The readings come from the word 踏む and the kanji 込, put together.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, but you haven't learned this for either 辛 or 抱 yet, so let's use a mnemonic to remember it: 

Think about how much <vocabulary>patience</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>endurance</vocabulary> your <reading>shin</reading>s (しん) need to have to be good at <reading>bo</reading>wling (ぼう). You won't get any strikes with weak shins!

Note that the ぼう reading is the rendaku'd reading for 抱.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You are trying <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary> from something chasing you, but you can't run fast because of your <reading>knee</reading> (に). You try to run, but it keeps holding you back. Feel the fear and pain of running with a hurt knee, and curse that knee of yours for holding you back.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Each reading has a slightly different meaning. Here's some mnemonics to help you remember them:

You need <vocabulary>to avoid</vocabulary> people who drink <reading>sake</reading> (さけ) all the time. Why? Because when they get drunk you'll have <vocabulary>to dodge</vocabulary> the <reading>yo</reading>-yos (よ) they spin at you. Sake makes you want to toss the ol' yo-yo around. Avoid them or you'll have to get good at dodging!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 頼む.
The reading is a bit different from 頼む, however. It's たよ, because you go to rely on your friends so much they become <reading>tiyored</reading> (たよ). They say "tired" like that, for some reason.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You do know that reading, but this uses a different one, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

There's nothing you love <vocabulary>to eat</vocabulary> more than <reading>coo</reading>kies (く). You could eat them day and night, but watch out, as that might get a little… time-consuming.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them for 香 and 料, but not for 辛, so here's a mnemonic to help:

The cabinet you keep your <vocabulary>spices</vocabulary> in is in a terrible place on the floor, and you keep banging your <reading>shin</reading> (しん) on it. Ouch!
The reading comes from 馬鹿.
You already learned 馬鹿, so as long as you can remember it twice in a row, you should be able to read this too!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
